title: How to Hang Mason Jars on Wood

steps.headline: Purchase finished wood craft cut outs for a simple project.
steps.description: Popular online suppliers and arts and crafts stores sell various kinds of wood cutouts specifically designed for projects like these. You can use wood pieces designed to hold single mason jars, or long wood pieces designed for 3 or more. E-commerce crafts sites are great places to find finished wood pieces that have been handmade by artists from around the world. The more popular suppliers like Amazon typically sell unfinished wood. The most common wood cutouts are 12 inch (30 cm) long wood and ⁄8 inch (0.32 cm) thick. Ideal pallet width is 5.375 inches (13.65 cm). If you purchase finished wood, you're ready to drill the screw holes!

steps.headline: Cut your pallet wood into four 8.7 inch (22 cm) pieces.
steps.description: For larger pieces of unfinished wood, you need to cut them down to sizes appropriate for your mason jars. Place the wood onto the surface of a band saw. Position your left hand on the bottom-left corner and your right on the bottom-right corner. Firmly push the wood through the saw, using your thumbs to push it forward and your remaining 4 fingers to press downward on the top of the wood. You can also use a table saw, jigsaw, or handsaw. Although you don't have to use8.6875 inch (22.066 cm) pieces, they approximate the golden ratio, which is aesthetically pleasing.

steps.headline: Sand your tablets down using 220-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Unfinished wood must be sanded to make lacquer application more effective. If you're using sandpaper, line it along a block of wood and rub it with the grain of the wood. For those going for a rustic look, a quick sanding is enough. If you want a cleaner look, continue sanding until your boards are smooth. Sanding against the direction of the grain can destroy wood fibers—always sand with the grain when possible. Purchase sanding guns for less labor-intensive sanding. To use these products, place the sandpaper to you wood, pull the trigger, and drag the sandpaper across the wood.

steps.headline: Draw a center line on the long axis on the front of each board.
steps.description: Use a ruler to mark the center along the 2 small sides of the board. Connect these points using a ruler and a pencil to create the horizontal center axis. Use your thumb, index, and middle fingers of your non-dominant hand to hold the ruler in place as you draw the center line.

steps.headline: Mark a circle on the lines 4 inches (10 cm) from the top of each board.
steps.description: Each of these circles will be used as a marker for the holes that well attach your clamps.

steps.headline: Drill a ⁄64 inch (0.28 cm) pilot hole about 3/4 of the way through the circle.
steps.description: This hole will be for the screw that secures your clamps. Stand at one of the short sides of the board facing the middle and place the palm of your non-dominant hand onto side closest to you. Keep your fingers closed together, your thumb pointed outward, and squeeze the trigger of your drill while applying downward pressure to the 4 inches (10 cm) mark with your non-dominant hand. You can purchase ⁄64 inch (0.28 cm) drill pieces from home hardware stores. Use your mark and axis line from the previous step as a guide.

steps.headline: Apply 2 to 3 coats of spray lacquer on unfinished wood.
steps.description: Create a safe work area and place your wood pieces on top of a newspaper. Keep a distance of 8 to 12 inches (20 to 30 cm) between the tip of your spray can and the wood. Always start spraying before you reach the wood. Move across and down the wood pieces with the spray, and move the can past each edge before you stop spraying to maintain consistency. Avoid spraying your lacquer in temperatures below 65 °F (18 °C) or when humidity is more than 65%. Wait about 48 hours between each coat (unless the manufacturer of the lacquer states otherwise in the instructions).

steps.headline: Mark a star 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) from the top of the back center line.
steps.description: This star will mark the spot for your hanging hole. Draw a center line along the long axis of the back of the board. Measure the center of the 2 shorter sides of the wood piece and mark them. Afterwards, connect the points using a ruler and a pencil, and draw the star. As you draw the center line, hold the ruler in place using the middle and index fingers of your non-dominant hand.

steps.headline: Drill a ⁄16 inch (0.79 cm) pilot hole through the star.
steps.description: Position yourself at the bottom of the board facing the top. Place the thumb of your non-dominant hand along the left side of the wood and the rest of your fingers on the right. Press down with your palm, pull the trigger and drill a hole in the star to a depth of approximately ⁄8 inch (0.95 cm). For this hole, use a Brad Point drill bit.

steps.headline: Drill a keyhole bit into the star hole and move it 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) toward the top.
steps.description: Creating this new opening in the board will allow it to hang from a nail on the wall more effectively. Begin drilling in each hole and move up 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) toward the top of each board. Use your non-dominant hand to move the drill up toward the top, and then back down. Hold the board in the place using your dominant hand. Once you're finished drilling the hole, turn the drill off and hold the router drill firmly with one hand until the bit stops spinning. If you don't have a router drill, you can skip this step and use your pilot hole to hang your wood. Don't attempt to use a router bit with a standard electric drill—you could end up damaging both the tool and the bit.

steps.headline: Score a hole in your hose clamps using the cut-off wheel on a rotary tool.
steps.description: Hold each hosing clamp between your thumb. When cutting the hole, hold the tip of the rotary tool closest to the blade with your thumb and index finger. Let the long bottom end rest against the knuckles of your remaining fingers. Cut the hole into 2 of the vertical metal slits to make room for a screw. Make sure that your hosing clamps are wide enough for the jars before scoring any holes in them. Mark each hole spot on your hose clamps prior to scoring them using permanent marker. Wear cut-resistant gloves for safety. If you don't have access to a rotary tool, you can also use a standard electric drill—you'll just have to put more force behind the drill to pierce the metal. Use a titanium drill bit for the best results.

steps.headline: Screw your clamps into the pilot holes on the front of each board.
steps.description: Insert your screws into the holes your scored into your clamps and then place the screws into the holes. Hold your clamps in between your thumb and use the rest of your fingers to hold it steady. Screw it in with your other hand. Don't screw the clamps all the way in just yet.

steps.headline: Slide your jars into the clamps and tighten them in.
steps.description: Position each jar straight along the length of the board. After placing each jar into this clamp, continue tightening the screws holding each clamp to the board using your electric drill. Grip one side of the jar as you tighten the screw to hold it steady.

steps.headline: Hang your wall hangings from anchor screws in your wall.
steps.description: Ideally, you already have some anchor screws in the location you want to hook your mason jars. If not, you'll have to install anchor screws on your own. Fill your jars with decorations like candles or flowers.
